observed huge apparition marching round and

the haunted knoll. Nothing could be more ROMAN
tic here, fores throwing its giant shadows ACROSS
fields and c0pses. and little streams stealing forth to
the broad moonshine; there, gorgeous lake, throw
ing up millions of sparklcs among the zephyrs that
wantoned upon its bosom-and yonder, tall figure


in white, stalking over the base ola dapidated dung
heap!


ssAh !" sighed the damsel, audibly, 81 wish to

ting into the room, then, Pm the boy; aunt Waty,s
got license. and iii fetch the parson in ajify''-
and away he sped, while Miss Waitsti!l unraveed

ster re-appeared. dragging in his reverence, wrap
ped in amazement, and homespun sheet: the latter
happening to be just withdrawn from the neghborng

AGENTS..

To the eicuatioa Of Gen. ANDREW JACKSON, to


the Chig .Magistracy Of these U. STATES.
When. in the of public events, it becomes
necessary for one party to oppose the political Chief
who, to the surprise of the nations of the earth,
supported by another for deniiied and lofty sta
ton, for which the fiat of nature and of natures God
disquallties hima decent respect for the advance.
ment Of their requires that they should declare
the reasons which impel them to the opposition
We hold these truths TO be self eviden--that GER
tain requisites necessary In Chief Magistrate
That amongst these, respect for the laws knowi-
edge of the constitutions experience in public affairs.
| and acquaintance with the political and diplomatic
history Of the country. That the generous and en-
lightenet support or his fellow citizens, is the high
est incentive OF the Patriot and that capricious dis
trust OF public servants is conducive to aesposm
as unsuspecting confidence. Prudence, indeed, will
dictate that an administration once established,
should not be changed for light and transient causes
and accordingly our experience hath shewn, that the
nation is more disposed to renew its confidence
when merted. than to crafty tactlous opposition by
qualtennal changes. And when Il long course Of
abuse anddenunciaton, pursuing invariably the same
object evinces design to destroy the admnlstra-
ton, tho pure the Angels at the right hand of
God" it is the right, il is the duty of its friends, to
] throw aside all forbearance, and boldly to inquire
into the pretenslons of the Candidate thus suppor-
leu. CuCn mas Doen lne lnfuIlateu COnuuCl Vi Lac


opposition, and such is now the necessity, which


constrans to declare, that the history OF AN
DREW JACKSON, is replete with Incorporate


bursts of passion, arbitrary measures and gross vo-


lations of the constitution-a going TO show his un


fitness for the first office in our government.-Tc


prove this let facts be submitted to candid world
He has in the outset of his military career, re-


fused to obey order of government directing hin
!, to disband his army.


He has carried on war against the Indians in a mer


ciless spirit, and hurled upon them an undlstingush
ed destruction of all ages, sexes, and conditions.
r He has suspended the proceedings of eglsla


tive body, for opposing with manly hrmness, his in
!. vasons on the rights of the people.


j He has arrested Printer for venturing to pub


lsh structures on bis high handed conduct thus vio
lang the liberty of the pressa liberty lnestimablt
:. to US and formidable to tyrants only.


He has not only treated with contempt the writ o
9 habeas corpus. but arrested the Judge who issued
it-thus rendering the military independent Of, and
J., superior to the civil power.


4 lie has, fortnight after the battle of Orleans
and after peace made, signed an order for the
: execution of six mllitiamen, whose only crime was
returning to their homes by advice of their officers
l., their term of service having expired.


# He has, after the news of peace was known, or
t. dered the execution Of eight regulars, found guilty
Q of deseron--a waste ofhuman blood, not called for
e az an example, since they shot in detail, in a
place remote from the army. at which there was moi
v troops suificientt to execute them in body.

CONDITIONS.

THE Vice Presidency.-In different parts Of the
Union, nominations begin to be made for the Vice
Presidency Soon after the termination Of the last
Session of Congress, the reader will recollect we
mentioned the rumor, then very prevalent, that Mr.
CALHOUN was not to be supported for the Vice Press
idency by the Combination we might have added
(but we do not remember that we dit) that this de-
termination made sine qua non by an honoraA
BILE SENATOR without whose accession to the party it
would, even in the Senate, have been in decided
minority. Recent indications, induce US to suppose.
that it is now determined, by the Southern part Of
the Combination, that Mr. Calhoun shall be upheld,
at all hazards which determination appears to US
much more generous and magnanimous than the has
From the, National Journal.

village not Tar from salem, an universal gloom was
spread over the whole face of the country. for at |
least three miles round. The great mansion house,
with all its appurtenances, become the inheritance
on certain conditions, of three bereaved maiden sis
ters, full grown, and somewhat lapsing beyond |
certain age. faithful guardianship of their neice,
the Colone's only child, Miss Admirable Potts, |
was the tenure upsn which the elder ladies were to
.have and to hold the aforeg granted premises during
their natural lives.'' Now Miss Admirable was Of
that age wherein it is customary to think tenderly
of being thought Of and the indulgence of this pen
sve mood by the damse in question, may be deem
ed no transgresslon of the cannons of modesty the
reader hereof is adured to ransack the most ro-
mantle corner Of his memory, for such notions of
feminine grace as shall contribute to the formation
of very pretty picture of Miss Admirable Potts
Under such circumstances, it behooved the three
aunts to be especially scrupulous in regard to the
behaviour OF their ward duty which they resol-
we'd to exercise with the utmost vigilance and
rigor


Long sanctioned practice among matter of-fact
novests, demands a personal description Of those
characters wherewith the writer chooseth to adorn
his tale. As for the Colonel, his demise is alread
recorded-and no interest in what he ,Uns can be
supposed to engage the present generation. The
heroine herself as hath before been remarked being
wholly indescrbabe, is abandoned to the dreams Of
fancy. But there was triumvrate of responsible
| spinsers, with whom the world longeth to become
| acquaned-to wit: in chrnnologc cal graduation,
| Miss Experience, Miss Watstill and Mss Silence
daughters Of the once late Faithful Potts, Esquire,
and Deliverance his wife. The eldest was p,im,
sharp-nosed fidgetty antique who tonk much pains
and some snuff; the next comfortable round faced,
solid body, with pleasant temper good appe-
| tie; the third dried poppy, wrinkled, soporific,
taclturn, and forbldding Such were the remnants
of an ancient race-the ultimate fragments of the
4 Pottses.


Hard by their family residence, lived the Rev.
Jeshuron Snarltext, tough long lmbed, gaunt
bachelor, OF two score years and upwards. This
gentleman, by OF numerous accidental calls
and divers voluntary counsels in domestic matters
had succeeded in fascinating nearly all the old ladies'


IN the parish 10 this charming faculty he added


lite airy taste-serving up his homilies to the highest
qualification of his auditory being gracously assist
ed hereunto by certain deyout and learned diyines,
whose accommodating fOlios and quartos performed
wonders similar to that which the angel wrought up
on the beast OF Balaam. moreover, his reverence
rcligousy remembered many rare scriptural iniunc-
tions, considering himself worse than any iniidel
should he neglect making provision for his wn bodi
lly comfort and deeming it above all things prtl-
dent, to make to himself friends of the mammon of


unrghteousness. Moved by considerations so weigh


ty, he had long goated ascant upon the person and


supposed chatteis of Miss Silence Pots--which she
nothing loah, perceived with all due quietudc and





reached its contemplated crisis, parson Snartext.
= in conversation day with Deacon Aonl ah Pitch
y er, grand-unce of the celebrated Mary Pitcher,


certaned, to his unspeakable horror that the wholt
5 Potts estate was entaied upon Miss Admirable


The Deacon.an honest, substantial, raight-forwart


woman, unconscious of the blow already nflict


ed by his disclosures proceeded to descant largely


upon the charms. both inherent and acquired, OF th
,e young gheiress-finishing his eulogium with yehe
le men hope that she might never become the prey
n fortunehunter, nor marry for aught but love
RI The astounded clergyman, seized with tit OF rum
81 nation stared through his spectaces, and went hi
m way.


Iv Deacon Pitchers seventh son, Rejoice Hardy,


robust swain of two-and-twenty. had for som


months harbored predilection towards young hlis
: Potts. The sentiment was reciprocal /; though II


one, as yet, but aunt Waitstl, possessed the mt


mentous secret and, in what manner she becom
ii its repository, is not material to relate. That sl
ce did obtain it, is beyond doubt-yet, it hath becom
les matter fhstory, that she kept it for whole weel
'es And whyp Because Rejoice, in her opinion, was
We very proper, fair spoken youngster; and an ear
m development mig ght have retarded that union whc


she hoped to see accomplished The parsons e


elusive attention to Miss Silence had ceased, an


Miss Experience was busls plotting match betwee
= his worship and the heiress !; but, parenthetca


speaking, she might have plotted till this very day
for Admirable was ncxorable.


'y One Sunday evening, the Kew. MIR. Snarltext wi
gossipping as usual with the ladies' at the mansic


house. As the evening waned, Miss Watstill wit
- drew to an adjoining apartment, whittier she ha


privately invited the Deacon's son. Through o


poste door, Silence ratired from pque, and Expe
per ience followed from design slawly they traipst
so onward in solemn staeliness to their respective
ers ches-and straighy all was still. The tall clock
the staircase had told eleven, and the refec
= ed Il mysterious sort Of brilliancy: Now for 10,
oy. scene. Mr.. Snartext commenceda discourse on IL


subject of ghosts-averrng that, for two nights


sucrossinn preciseIv at miIluoht he had distinct
A LOVE STORY.
FROM THE NANTUCKET INQUIRER.

tuition in the representatives of the people.
| He has insoently told the Gov ofGeorgia, you
sir as governor of the state, have right to give
IA military order, whilst am in the field''--thns
showing his contempt for the most important right
g reserved to the states.''


He has issued general order, directing the offl-
GERS in his military division, to disregard amy order
of the government which did not come through him.
He has, when the representatives OF the people


instituted an inquiry into his conduct manifested the
utmost indignation and endeavored to intimidate
| them by threats of violence.
| He has meditaed personal assault upon mems
| Der in his place in the Senate Chamber: and
prevented from executing it, only by the threat Of
the noble Decatur take his life if he made the att
tempt.
| He has, whilst governor of territory cited be-


fore him judge, whose sole offence was the issu-


ing, Gas his duty when applied to) the writ Of
habeas corpus.


i He has in the same capacity, promulgated DEGREES,
4 illegal and oppressive-declaring at the time, that


as governor of Florida, he invested with all the


powers exercised by the captain general of the ISL


and of Cuba, powers foreign to our constitutions and


unacknowedged by our laws.


He has gravely stated, that had he been comtnarls


der of that military district he would have hung the


members of the Hartford Convention, under the


second seotion of the rules and regulations for the


government of the army--a latitude OF construction
! highly unwarrantabe and dangerous.





; Madisons reelection that as philosopher he
could not look with composure on blood and car
mage"


He has when a commissioner, negotiating with the
Indians stipulated for grant of land to himself,
which article of the treaty was not ratified by the
Senate of the United States.
He has whilst general in the army Of the United
|States ntruded into the legislature OF his own state,
and harrangued the members on an important ques-
ton then pending.


He has written numerous electioneering leers---s


in spite of the sentiment of the lamened Lowndess


which he has affected TO adopt.
o He has whilst in the Senate of the United States,
contented himself with giving negative vote, on
IS Nomination brought about (he being according to his
own story conuzani Of the tac by bribery and corA
is ruption-thus abandoning his solemn duty and be-
l. tray ing his constituents.


d He has at his own iresde'' circulated a bass
). slander against the second officer in the cabinet nnd
e lis not supported in his statement by the witness


whom he summons.


: He has to promote his own views taken 10 his
bosom man, long his deadliest enemy, and whose
l. life he once attempted.


), In every one of these outrages he has been jisti,
c fed by his adherents repeated remonstrance3
l. have been answered only by repeated injury. y


man, whose character is thus marked, by every act;
which may define tryran, is unfit to be the rules
l. of free people.


II Nor have been wanting in attentions 10 our
l. fellow ireemen. We have warned them from time
to timc OF the attempt Of combination, to extend
,e military despotism over us. We have reminded
, them of Caesar, Cromwell and Napoleon. We
have appealed to their native good and love Of
Of liberty and we have conured them, by the ties of
,e our common country, to lrown upon man, whose
A. elevation will inevitably give death blow to the
of republic. They will not be deaf to the voice Of
to reason and experience but acquesce in our denns
re citation of his pretensions to civil office, and hold
r. him. as we hold the rest of military chietains-
he useful in war--ln peace dangerous
ch We, therefore, the friends OF the present admblss
traton of the general government, appealing to the
tie supreme law of the land for the protection OF Off
o. persons do in the and by virtue OF those prn@
M ciples which we have inherited, soemnly publish
10 and declare that ANDREW JACKSON is, and al.
d. ways will be, rash, incompetent and dangerous-thae
e. he destitute of all pretenson to the chair OF state,
ina and that all political cennexion between him and our


ourishing Republic, is and ought to be totally de-
,r. nounced and that in free and republican sates
h. civil virtues talents and political experiences are,


and of right ought to be, preferred to fame, exclus
la sively military And for the support of this declas
in ration, with firm reliance the good sense OF the


community, we mutually pledge to each other Ucr
,b- votes, our influence and ceaseless efforts.

ment Of their requires that they should declare

That amongst these, respect for the laws knowi-

| and acquaintance with the political and diplomatic

as unsuspecting confidence. Prudence, indeed, will

and accordingly our experience hath shewn, that the

opposition, and such is now the necessity, which

prove this let facts be submitted to candid world

:. to US and formidable to tyrants only.


He has not only treated with contempt the writ o
9 habeas corpus. but arrested the Judge who issued
it-thus rendering the military independent Of, and
J., superior to the civil power.


4 lie has, fortnight after the battle of Orleans
and after peace made, signed an order for the
: execution of six mllitiamen, whose only crime was
returning to their homes by advice of their officers
l., their term of service having expired.


# He has, after the news of peace was known, or
t. dered the execution Of eight regulars, found guilty
Q of deseron--a waste ofhuman blood, not called for
e az an example, since they shot in detail, in a
place remote from the army. at which there was moi
v troops suificientt to execute them in body.

full articles.headline: From the, National Journal.
full articles.article:
THE Vice Presidency.-In different parts Of the
Union, nominations begin to be made for the Vice
Presidency Soon after the termination Of the last
Session of Congress, the reader will recollect we
mentioned the rumor, then very prevalent, that Mr.
CALHOUN was not to be supported for the Vice Press
idency by the Combination we might have added
(but we do not remember that we dit) that this de-
termination made sine qua non by an honoraA
BILE SENATOR without whose accession to the party it
would, even in the Senate, have been in decided
minority. Recent indications, induce US to suppose.
that it is now determined, by the Southern part Of
the Combination, that Mr. Calhoun shall be upheld,
at all hazards which determination appears to US
much more generous and magnanimous than the has

full articles.headline:
A LOVE STORY.

FROM THE NANTUCKET INQUIRER.
full articles.article:
village not Tar from salem, an universal gloom was
spread over the whole face of the country. for at |
least three miles round. The great mansion house,
with all its appurtenances, become the inheritance
on certain conditions, of three bereaved maiden sis
ters, full grown, and somewhat lapsing beyond |
certain age. faithful guardianship of their neice,
the Colone's only child, Miss Admirable Potts, |
was the tenure upsn which the elder ladies were to
.have and to hold the aforeg granted premises during
their natural lives.'' Now Miss Admirable was Of
that age wherein it is customary to think tenderly
of being thought Of and the indulgence of this pen
sve mood by the damse in question, may be deem
ed no transgresslon of the cannons of modesty the
reader hereof is adured to ransack the most ro-
mantle corner Of his memory, for such notions of
feminine grace as shall contribute to the formation
of very pretty picture of Miss Admirable Potts
Under such circumstances, it behooved the three
aunts to be especially scrupulous in regard to the
behaviour OF their ward duty which they resol-
we'd to exercise with the utmost vigilance and
rigor


Long sanctioned practice among matter of-fact
novests, demands a personal description Of those
characters wherewith the writer chooseth to adorn
his tale. As for the Colonel, his demise is alread
recorded-and no interest in what he ,Uns can be
supposed to engage the present generation. The
heroine herself as hath before been remarked being
wholly indescrbabe, is abandoned to the dreams Of
fancy. But there was triumvrate of responsible
| spinsers, with whom the world longeth to become
| acquaned-to wit: in chrnnologc cal graduation,
| Miss Experience, Miss Watstill and Mss Silence
daughters Of the once late Faithful Potts, Esquire,
and Deliverance his wife. The eldest was p,im,
sharp-nosed fidgetty antique who tonk much pains
and some snuff; the next comfortable round faced,
solid body, with pleasant temper good appe-
| tie; the third dried poppy, wrinkled, soporific,
taclturn, and forbldding Such were the remnants
of an ancient race-the ultimate fragments of the
4 Pottses.


Hard by their family residence, lived the Rev.
Jeshuron Snarltext, tough long lmbed, gaunt
bachelor, OF two score years and upwards. This
gentleman, by OF numerous accidental calls
and divers voluntary counsels in domestic matters
had succeeded in fascinating nearly all the old ladies'


IN the parish 10 this charming faculty he added


lite airy taste-serving up his homilies to the highest
qualification of his auditory being gracously assist
ed hereunto by certain deyout and learned diyines,
whose accommodating fOlios and quartos performed
wonders similar to that which the angel wrought up
on the beast OF Balaam. moreover, his reverence
rcligousy remembered many rare scriptural iniunc-
tions, considering himself worse than any iniidel
should he neglect making provision for his wn bodi
lly comfort and deeming it above all things prtl-
dent, to make to himself friends of the mammon of


unrghteousness. Moved by considerations so weigh


ty, he had long goated ascant upon the person and


supposed chatteis of Miss Silence Pots--which she
nothing loah, perceived with all due quietudc and





reached its contemplated crisis, parson Snartext.
= in conversation day with Deacon Aonl ah Pitch
y er, grand-unce of the celebrated Mary Pitcher,


certaned, to his unspeakable horror that the wholt
5 Potts estate was entaied upon Miss Admirable


The Deacon.an honest, substantial, raight-forwart


woman, unconscious of the blow already nflict


ed by his disclosures proceeded to descant largely


upon the charms. both inherent and acquired, OF th
,e young gheiress-finishing his eulogium with yehe
le men hope that she might never become the prey
n fortunehunter, nor marry for aught but love
RI The astounded clergyman, seized with tit OF rum
81 nation stared through his spectaces, and went hi
m way.


Iv Deacon Pitchers seventh son, Rejoice Hardy,


robust swain of two-and-twenty. had for som


months harbored predilection towards young hlis
: Potts. The sentiment was reciprocal /; though II


one, as yet, but aunt Waitstl, possessed the mt


mentous secret and, in what manner she becom
ii its repository, is not material to relate. That sl
ce did obtain it, is beyond doubt-yet, it hath becom
les matter fhstory, that she kept it for whole weel
'es And whyp Because Rejoice, in her opinion, was
We very proper, fair spoken youngster; and an ear
m development mig ght have retarded that union whc


she hoped to see accomplished The parsons e


elusive attention to Miss Silence had ceased, an


Miss Experience was busls plotting match betwee
= his worship and the heiress !; but, parenthetca


speaking, she might have plotted till this very day
for Admirable was ncxorable.


'y One Sunday evening, the Kew. MIR. Snarltext wi
gossipping as usual with the ladies' at the mansic


house. As the evening waned, Miss Watstill wit
- drew to an adjoining apartment, whittier she ha


privately invited the Deacon's son. Through o


poste door, Silence ratired from pque, and Expe
per ience followed from design slawly they traipst
so onward in solemn staeliness to their respective
ers ches-and straighy all was still. The tall clock
the staircase had told eleven, and the refec
= ed Il mysterious sort Of brilliancy: Now for 10,
oy. scene. Mr.. Snartext commenceda discourse on IL


subject of ghosts-averrng that, for two nights


sucrossinn preciseIv at miIluoht he had distinct

full articles.headline: JNo. 81.
full articles.article:
tuition in the representatives of the people.
| He has insoently told the Gov ofGeorgia, you
sir as governor of the state, have right to give
IA military order, whilst am in the field''--thns
showing his contempt for the most important right
g reserved to the states.''


He has issued general order, directing the offl-
GERS in his military division, to disregard amy order
of the government which did not come through him.
He has, when the representatives OF the people


instituted an inquiry into his conduct manifested the
utmost indignation and endeavored to intimidate
| them by threats of violence.
| He has meditaed personal assault upon mems
| Der in his place in the Senate Chamber: and
prevented from executing it, only by the threat Of
the noble Decatur take his life if he made the att
tempt.
| He has, whilst governor of territory cited be-


fore him judge, whose sole offence was the issu-


ing, Gas his duty when applied to) the writ Of
habeas corpus.


i He has in the same capacity, promulgated DEGREES,
4 illegal and oppressive-declaring at the time, that


as governor of Florida, he invested with all the


powers exercised by the captain general of the ISL


and of Cuba, powers foreign to our constitutions and


unacknowedged by our laws.


He has gravely stated, that had he been comtnarls


der of that military district he would have hung the


members of the Hartford Convention, under the


second seotion of the rules and regulations for the


government of the army--a latitude OF construction
! highly unwarrantabe and dangerous.





; Madisons reelection that as philosopher he
could not look with composure on blood and car
mage"


He has when a commissioner, negotiating with the
Indians stipulated for grant of land to himself,
which article of the treaty was not ratified by the
Senate of the United States.
He has whilst general in the army Of the United
|States ntruded into the legislature OF his own state,
and harrangued the members on an important ques-
ton then pending.


He has written numerous electioneering leers---s


in spite of the sentiment of the lamened Lowndess


which he has affected TO adopt.
o He has whilst in the Senate of the United States,
contented himself with giving negative vote, on
IS Nomination brought about (he being according to his
own story conuzani Of the tac by bribery and corA
is ruption-thus abandoning his solemn duty and be-
l. tray ing his constituents.


d He has at his own iresde'' circulated a bass
). slander against the second officer in the cabinet nnd
e lis not supported in his statement by the witness


whom he summons.


: He has to promote his own views taken 10 his
bosom man, long his deadliest enemy, and whose
l. life he once attempted.


), In every one of these outrages he has been jisti,
c fed by his adherents repeated remonstrance3
l. have been answered only by repeated injury. y


man, whose character is thus marked, by every act;
which may define tryran, is unfit to be the rules
l. of free people.


II Nor have been wanting in attentions 10 our
l. fellow ireemen. We have warned them from time
to timc OF the attempt Of combination, to extend
,e military despotism over us. We have reminded
, them of Caesar, Cromwell and Napoleon. We
have appealed to their native good and love Of
Of liberty and we have conured them, by the ties of
,e our common country, to lrown upon man, whose
A. elevation will inevitably give death blow to the
of republic. They will not be deaf to the voice Of
to reason and experience but acquesce in our denns
re citation of his pretensions to civil office, and hold
r. him. as we hold the rest of military chietains-
he useful in war--ln peace dangerous
ch We, therefore, the friends OF the present admblss
traton of the general government, appealing to the
tie supreme law of the land for the protection OF Off
o. persons do in the and by virtue OF those prn@
M ciples which we have inherited, soemnly publish
10 and declare that ANDREW JACKSON is, and al.
d. ways will be, rash, incompetent and dangerous-thae
e. he destitute of all pretenson to the chair OF state,
ina and that all political cennexion between him and our


ourishing Republic, is and ought to be totally de-
,r. nounced and that in free and republican sates
h. civil virtues talents and political experiences are,


and of right ought to be, preferred to fame, exclus
la sively military And for the support of this declas
in ration, with firm reliance the good sense OF the


community, we mutually pledge to each other Ucr
,b- votes, our influence and ceaseless efforts.
lie From the, National Journal
